RTCInboundRtpStreamStats.summary: The RTCInboundRtpStreamStats dictionary of the WebRTC API is used to report statistics related to the receiving end of an RTP stream on the local end of the .

remarks.para: The statistics can be obtained by iterating the returned by or until you find a report with the type of inbound-rtp.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsAudioLevel.summary: The audioLevel property of the dictionary indicates the audio level of the received (remote) track.

remarks.para:
The audioLevel is averaged over some small interval, using the algorithm described under .
The interval used is implementation dependent.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para: - for audio levels of local tracks (that are being sent)

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsAudioLevel.value: A real number.The value is between 0..1 (linear), where 1.0 represents 0 dBov (decibels relative to full scale (DBFS)), 0 represents silence, and 0.5 represents approximately 6 dB SPL change in the sound pressure level from 0 dBov.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsBytesReceived.summary: The bytesReceived property of the dictionary indicates the total number of bytes received so far from this synchronization source (SSRC), not including header and padding bytes.

remarks.para: The value can be used to calculate an approximation of the average media data rate:
The property value is reset to zero if the sender's SSRC identifier changes for any reason.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsCodecId.summary: The codecId property of the dictionary is a string that uniquely identifies the object that was inspected to produce the data in the for the {{Glossary("RTP")}} stream.

remarks.para: RTCInboundRtpStreamStats and RTCCodecStats objects are correlated by iterating the to find the statistics objects where RTCInboundRtpStreamStats.codecId is equal to .

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsCodecId.value: A string that contains the of the object that was inspected to produce the object associated with this RTP stream.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsConcealedSamples.summary: The concealedSamples property of the dictionary indicates the total number of concealed samples for the received audio track over the lifetime of this stats object.

remarks.para:
A concealed sample is a sample that was lost or arrived too late to be played out, and therefore had to be replaced with a locally generated synthesized sample.
Note that lost samples are reported in , while late packets are reported in .

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Packet loss concealment on Wikipedia

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsConcealmentEvent.summary: The concealmentEvents property of the dictionary indicates the total number of concealment events for the received audio track over the lifetime of this stats object.

remarks.para:
A concealed sample is a sample that was lost or arrived too late to be played out, and therefore had to be replaced with a locally generated synthesized sample.
Any number of consecutive concealed samples following a non-concealed sample comprise a single concealment event.
The value in this property will therefore be less than or equal to , which counts every sample.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Packet loss concealment on Wikipedia

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsEstimatedPlayout.summary: NOTE Experimental The estimatedPlayoutTimestamp property of the dictionary indicates the estimated playout time of this receiver's track.

remarks.para:
This is the Network Time Protocol (NTP) timestamp of the last playable audio sample or video frame that has a known timestamp, extrapolated with the time elapsed since it was ready to be played out.
In other words, it is the estimated current playout time of the track in the NTP clock time of the sender, and can be present even if there is no audio currently playing.
This can be used to estimate how much audio and video tracks from the same source are out of sync.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFecPacketsDiscar.summary: The fecPacketsDiscarded property of the dictionary indicates the number of {{Glossary("RTP")}} Forward Error Correction (FEC) packets that have been discarded.

remarks.para:
A FEC packet provides parity information that can be used to attempt to reconstruct RTP data packets which have been corrupted in transit.
This kind of packet might be discarded if all the packets that it covers have already been received or recovered using another FEC packet, or if the FEC packet arrived outside the recovery window and the lost RTP packets have already been skipped during playback as a result.
The value of includes these discarded packets.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFecPacketsReceiv.summary: The fecPacketsReceived property of the dictionary indicates how many Forward Error Correction (FEC) packets have been received by this RTP receiver from the remote peer.

remarks.para: A FEC packet provides parity information that can be used to attempt to reconstruct RTP data packets which have been corrupted in transit.
-{{RFC(5109)}} (RTP Payload Format for Generic Forward Error Correction)

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFrameHeight.summary: The frameHeight property of the dictionary indicates the height of the last decoded frame, in pixels.

remarks.para: Note that the resolution of the encoded frame may be lower than that of the media source, which is provided in .

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams, and before the first frame is decoded.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFramesAssembledF.summary: NOTE Experimental The framesAssembledFromMultiplePackets property of the dictionary indicates the total number of correctly decoded frames for this RTP stream that were assembled from more than one RTP packet.

remarks.para:
This property can be used with to determine the average assembly time: totalAssemblyTime / framesAssembledFromMultiplePacket.
A higher average assembly time might indicate network issues or inefficiencies in the receiving pipeline.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFramesDecoded.summary: The framesDecoded property of the dictionary indicates the total number of video frames which have been decoded successfully for this media source.

remarks.para: This represents the number of frames that would have been displayed assuming no frames were skipped.

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFramesPerSecond.summary: The framesPerSecond property of the dictionary indicates the number of frames decoded in the last second.

remarks.para: Note that this may be lower than the media source frame rate, which is provided in .

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFramesReceived.summary: The framesReceived property of the dictionary indicates the total number of complete frames received on this RTP stream over its lifetime.

remarks.para: Note that this may be lower than the total number of media source frames, which is provided in .

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFrameWidth.summary: The frameWidth property of the dictionary indicates the width of the last decoded frame, in pixels.

remarks.para: Note that the resolution of the encoded frame may be lower than that of the media source, which is provided in .

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for audio streams, or before the first frame is encoded.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsFreezeCount.summary: NOTE Experimental The freezeCount property of the dictionary indicates the total number of video freezes experienced by this receiver.

remarks.para:
A freeze is counted if the interval between two rendered frames is equal to or greater than the larger of "three times the average duration", or "the average + 150ms".
This ensures that the delay required to increment the freeze count scales appropriately with the frame rate.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsHeaderBytesRecei.summary: The headerBytesReceived property of the dictionary indicates the total number of RTP header and padding bytes received for this synchronization source (SSRC), including those sent in retransmissions.

remarks.para: Note that the total number of bytes received as payload over the transport is equal to: headerBytesReceived + .

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsId.summary: The id property of the dictionary is a string that uniquely identifies the object for which this object provides statistics.

remarks.para: Using the id, you can correlate this statistics object with others, in order to monitor statistics over time for a given WebRTC object, such as an , or an .

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsId.value: A string that uniquely identifies the object for which this RTCInboundRtpStreamStats object provides statistics.The format of the ID string is not defined by the specification, so you cannot reliably make any assumptions about the contents of the string, or assume that the format of the string will remain unchanged for a given object type.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsInsertedSamplesF.summary: The insertedSamplesForDeceleration property of the dictionary accumulates the difference between the number of samples received and the number of samples played out of the {{glossary("jitter","jitter buffer")}} while audio playout is slowed down.

remarks.para:
The WebRTC jitter buffer sets a target playout delay level such that the inflow and outflow of the jitter buffer should be approximately the same.
If the jitter buffer empties too quickly the audio sample that is next in line to be output may be "ahead of schedule", and the jitter buffer may slow down playout.
If the jitter buffer slows down the playout of the sample by inserting additional audio samples, this property indicates the accumulated number of such added samples.

Slowing down and/or speeding up the audio (as tracked with ) may result in audible warbling or other distortion.
The totals at the end of the call also give you some indication of how many samples or seconds were impacted, and insertedSamplesForDeceleration can be correlated with to get a relative measure of deceleration.
Logging insertedSamplesForDeceleration and removedSamplesForAcceleration in timeslices can be helpful for isolating the times at which the problem occurred and you can then correlate other metrics in the same timeslice to determine likely causes.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para:
-
-The better way in "How WebRTC's NetEQ Jitter Buffer Provides Smooth Audio" (webrtchacks.com, June 2025)

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsJitter.summary: The jitter property of the dictionary indicates the packet interarrival {{glossary("jitter")}} for this synchronization source (SSRC), in seconds.

remarks.para: The packet jitter is calculated as defined in {{rfc("RFC3550",,"6.4.1")}}.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsJitterBufferDela.summary: The jitterBufferDelay property of the dictionary indicates the accumulated time that all audio samples and complete video frames have spent in the {{glossary("jitter","jitter buffer")}}.

remarks.para:
For an audio sample the time is calculated from the time that the sample is received by the jitter buffer ("ingest timestamp"), until the time that the sample is emitted ("exit timestamp").
For a video frame, the ingest time is when the first packet in the frame was ingested until the time at which the whole frame exits the buffer.
Note that several audio samples in an RTP packet will have the same ingest timestamp but different exit timestamps, while a video frame might be split across a number of RTP packets.

jitterBufferDelay is incremented, along with , when samples or frames exit the buffer.
The average jitter buffer delay is jitterBufferDelay / jitterBufferEmittedCount.

The jitter buffer may hold samples/frames for a longer (or shorter) delay, allowing samples to build up in the buffer so that it can provide a more smooth and continuous playout.
A low and relatively constant jitterBufferDelay is desirable, as it indicates the buffer does not need to hold as many frames/samples, and the network is stable.
Higher values might indicate that the network is less reliable or predictable.
Similarly, a steady average delay indicates a more stable network, while a rising average delay indicates growing latency.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsJitterBufferEmit.summary: The jitterBufferEmittedCount property of the dictionary indicates the total number of audio samples and/or video frames that have come out of the {{glossary("jitter","jitter buffer")}}.

remarks.para:
The jitterBufferEmittedCount and are incremented when samples or frames exit the buffer.
The average jitter buffer delay is jitterBufferDelay / jitterBufferEmittedCount.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsJitterBufferMini.summary: The jitterBufferMinimumDelay property of the dictionary indicates the minimum {{glossary("jitter","jitter buffer")}} delay that might be achieved given only the network characteristics such as jitter and packet loss.

remarks.para:
The jitter buffer delay may be impacted by user settings such as , and WebRTC mechanisms such as AV synchronization.
jitterBufferMinimumDelay can be compared to the to examine the effect of these external factors on the delay.
The property is updated when is updated.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsJitterBufferTarg.summary: The jitterBufferTargetDelay property of the dictionary indicates the accumulated target {{glossary("jitter","jitter buffer")}} delay, in seconds.

remarks.para:
The target jitter buffer delay is the playout delay that the jitter buffer estimates that it needs to maintain in order to compensate for jitter and ensure smooth playback.
The estimate is affected by network variability and latency as well as mechanisms such as AV synchronization. Developers can influence it by setting the property.

The property is updated when is updated.
The average target jitter buffer delay is jitterBufferTargetDelay / jitterBufferEmittedCount.
The property can be compared to the average of the to determine the effects of external factors on the target, such as the configured jitterBufferTarget hint.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsKeyFramesDecoded.summary:
The keyFramesDecoded property of the dictionary represents the total number of key frames successfully decoded in this RTP media stream.
This includes, for example, key frames in VP8 ({{rfc("6386")}}) or IDR-frames in H.264 ({{rfc("6184")}}).

remarks.para: Note that the number of delta frames is calculated by subtracting this value from the total number of frames ( - keyFramesEncoded).

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsKind.summary: The kind property of the dictionary is a string indicating whether the described {{Glossary("RTP")}} stream contains audio or video media.

remarks.para:
This string will always be the same as the of the object carried by the stream.
It will also match the media type of the codec associated with this statistics objects (i.e., the MIME type of the associated codec's property).

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsKind.value: The kind is always one of:

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsLastPacketReceiv.summary: The lastPacketReceivedTimestamp property of the dictionary indicates the time at which the most recently received packet arrived from this source.
RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsLastPacketReceiv.value:
A which specifies the time at which the most recently received packet arrived on this RTP stream.
NOTEThis value differs from the ,
which represents the time at which the statistics object was created.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsMid.summary:
The mid property of the dictionary is a string that contains the media id negotiated between the local and remote peers.
This uniquely identifies the pairing of source and destination for the transceiver's stream.
RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsMid.value: The value of the corresponding , unless that value is null, in which case this statistic property is not present.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsNackCount.summary: The nackCount property of the dictionary indicates the number of times the receiver sent a NACK packet to the sender.

remarks.para: A NACK (Negative ACKnowledgement, also called "Generic NACK") packet tells the sender that one or more of the RTP packets it sent were lost in transport.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsPacketsDiscarded.summary: The packetsDiscarded property of the dictionary indicates the cumulative number of {{Glossary("RTP")}} packets that have been discarded by the {{glossary("jitter","jitter buffer")}} due to late or early-arrival, and are hence not played out.

remarks.para: The value does not include packets that are discarded to due to packet duplication.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsPacketsDiscarded.value: A positive integer value.This is calculated as defined in {{rfc("7002",,"3.2")}} (and appendix A.a.)

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsPacketsLost.summary: The packetsLost property of the dictionary returns the total number of {{Glossary("RTP")}} packets lost from the synchronization source (SSRC) since the beginning of reception.

remarks.para: Note that this can be negative.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsPacketsLost.value:
An integer value.The value is determined by subtracting the number of packets received from the number of packets that are expected.
The number of packets that are expected is calculated in a way that assumes that all packets only need to be sent once (based on sequence numbers), while the number of packets received also includes any packets that had to be resent (and hence may be bigger).
For more information see the "cumulative number of packets lost" section in {{RFC("3550", "", "6.4.1")}}.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsPacketsReceived.summary: The packetsReceived property of the dictionary returns the total number of {{Glossary("RTP")}} packets received from the synchronization source (SSRC) of this stream, including retransmissions.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsPauseCount.summary: NOTE Experimental The pauseCount property of the dictionary indicates the total number of pauses experienced by this receiver.

remarks.para: A pause is counted when a new frame is rendered more than 5 seconds after the last frame was rendered.
The average pause duration can be calculated using totalPausesDuration / pauseCount.

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsPlayoutId.summary: NOTE Experimental The playoutId property of the dictionary indicates the of the object that corresponds to this stream.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsQpSum.summary: The qpSum property of the dictionary indicates the sum of the Quantization Parameter (QP) values for every frame sent or received on the video track corresponding to this RTCInboundRtpStreamStats object.

remarks.para: In general, a larger numbers indicates that the video data is more heavily compressed.

blockquote.para: This value is only available for video media.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsRemoteId.summary: The remoteId property of the dictionary specifies the of the object representing the remote peer's which is sending the media to the local peer.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsRemovedSamplesFo.summary: The removedSamplesForAcceleration property of the dictionary accumulates the difference between the number of samples played out of the {{glossary("jitter","jitter buffer")}} and the number of samples received while audio playout is sped up.

remarks.para:
The WebRTC jitter buffer sets a target playout delay level such that the inflow and outflow of the jitter buffer should be approximately the same.
If the jitter buffer empties too slowly the audio sample that is next in line to be output may be "behind schedule", and the engine may speed up playout to catch up.
If the engine speeds up playout by removing some audio samples, this property indicates the accumulated number of such removed samples.

Speeding up or slowing down the audio (as tracked with ) may result in audible warbling or other distortion.
The totals at the end of the call also give you some indication of how many samples or seconds were impacted, and removedSamplesForAcceleration can be correlated with to get a relative measure of acceleration.
Logging insertedSamplesForDeceleration and removedSamplesForAcceleration in timeslices can be helpful for isolating the times at which the problem occurred and you can then correlate other metrics in the same timeslice to determine likely causes.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para:
-
-The better way in "How WebRTC's NetEQ Jitter Buffer Provides Smooth Audio" (webrtchacks.com, June 2025)

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsSilentConcealedS.summary: The silentConcealedSamples property of the dictionary indicates the total number of silent concealed samples for the received audio track over the lifetime of this stats object.

remarks.para:
A concealed sample is a sample that was lost or arrived too late to be played out, and therefore had to be replaced with a locally generated synthesized sample.
A silent concealed sample is one where the inserted sample is either silent or comfort noise.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Packet loss concealment on Wikipedia

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsSsrc.summary: The ssrc property of the dictionary identifies the synchronization source (SSRC) of this stream of {{Glossary("RTP")}} packets.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTimestamp.summary: The timestamp property of the dictionary is a object specifying the time at which the data in the object was sampled.
RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTimestamp.value: A value indicating the time at which the activity described by the statistics in this object was recorded, in milliseconds elapsed since the beginning of January 1, 1970, UTC.The value should be accurate to within a few milliseconds but may not be entirely precise, either because of hardware or operating system limitations or because of fingerprinting protection in the form of reduced clock precision or accuracy.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalAssemblyTim.summary: NOTE Experimental The totalAssemblyTime property of the dictionary indicates the total time spent assembling successfully decoded video frames that were transported in multiple RTP packets.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalAudioEnergy.summary: The totalAudioEnergy property of the dictionary represents the total audio energy of a received audio track over the lifetime of this stats object.

remarks.para: The total energy across a particular duration can be determined by subtracting the value of this property returned by two different getStats() calls.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para: - for audio energy of local tracks (that are being sent)

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalAudioEnergy.value:
A number produced by summing the energy of every sample over the lifetime of this stats object.The energy of each sample is calculated by dividing the sample's value by the highest-intensity encodable value, squaring the result, and then multiplying by the duration of the sample in seconds.
This is shown as an equation below:Note that if multiple audio channels are used, the audio energy of a sample refers to the highest energy of any channel.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalDecodeTime.summary: The totalDecodeTime property of the dictionary indicates the total time spend decoding frames for this media source/stream, in seconds.

remarks.para: The time it takes to decode one frame is the time passed between feeding the decoder a frame and the decoder returning decoded data for that frame.
The number of decoded frames is given in , and the average decode time is totalDecodeTime / framesDecoded.

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalFreezesDura.summary: NOTE Experimental The totalFreezesDuration property of the dictionary indicates the total time that the video in this stream has spent frozen, in seconds.

remarks.para: A freeze is counted if the interval between two rendered frames is equal or greater than the larger of "three times the average duration", or "the average + 150ms", and the time taken between frames is added to the totalFreezesDuration.
The average freeze duration can be calculated using totalFreezesDuration / freezeCount.

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalInterFrameD.summary:
The totalInterFrameDelay property of the dictionary indicates the total accumulated time between consecutively rendered frames, in seconds.
It is recorded after each frame is rendered.

remarks.para: The inter-frame delay variance can be calculated from totalInterFrameDelay, , and according to the formula: (totalSquaredInterFrameDelay - totalInterFrameDelay^2/ framesRendered)/framesRendered.

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalPausesDurat.summary: NOTE Experimental The totalPausesDuration property of the dictionary indicates the total time that the video in this stream has spent paused, in seconds

remarks.para: A pause is counted when a new frame is rendered more than 5 seconds after the last frame was rendered, and the time taken between frames is added to the totalPausesDuration.
The average pause duration can be calculated using totalPausesDuration / pauseCount.

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalProcessingD.summary: The totalProcessingDelay property of the dictionary indicates the total accumulated time spent processing audio or video samples, in seconds.

remarks.para:
The processing time for each audio or video sample is calculated from the time the first RTP packet is received (reception timestamp) to the time that the corresponding sample or frame is decoded (decoded timestamp).
At this point the audio sample or video frame is fully decoded by the decoder and is ready for playout by the .

For audio streams, an RTP packet may contain multiple audio samples: these will share the same reception timestamp.
For video streams, a complete frame may arrive in several RTP packets, and the reception timestamp is that of the first RTP packet that was received that contains data for the frame.
In both cases the decoded timestamp is the time at which the sample or frame is ready to play.

For video, the property only accumulates for decoded frames (not those that were dropped).
The average processing delay can be calculated by dividing the totalProcessingDelay with the . <!-- audio samples can't get average - totalSamplesDecoded not in spec yet or implemented -->

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalSamplesDura.summary:
The totalSamplesDuration property of the dictionary indicates the total duration of all audio samples that have been received.
In other words, the current duration of the track.

remarks.para: This can be used with to compute an average audio level over different intervals.

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

remarks.para:
- for the audio duration of sent samples.
-

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalSamplesRece.summary: The totalSamplesReceived property of the dictionary indicates the total number of samples received on this stream, including .

blockquote.para: The value is undefined for video streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTotalSquaredInte.summary:
The totalSquaredInterFrameDelay property of the dictionary indicates the sum of the square of each inter-frame delay between consecutively rendered frames.
It is recorded after each frame is rendered.

remarks.para: The inter-frame delay variance be calculated from , totalSquaredInterFrameDelay, and , according to the formula: (totalSquaredInterFrameDelay - totalInterFrameDelay^2/ framesRendered)/framesRendered.

blockquote.para: The property is undefined for audio streams.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTrackIdentifier.summary: The trackIdentifier property of the dictionary is a string that identifies the MediaStreamTrack associated with the inbound stream.

remarks.para: This value will match the value of the associated track.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTrackIdentifier.value: A string that identifies the associated media track.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTransportId.summary: The transportId property of the dictionary is a string that uniquely identifies the associated statistics object for this RTP stream's underlying transport.

remarks.para: RTCInboundRtpStreamStats and RTCTransportStats objects are correlated by iterating the to find the statistics objects where RTCInboundRtpStreamStats.transportId is equal to .

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsTransportId.value: A string that contains the of the object that was inspected to produce the object associated with this RTP stream.

RTCInboundRtpStreamStatsType.summary: The type property of the dictionary is a string with the value "inbound-rtp".

remarks.para:
Different statistics are obtained by iterating the object returned by a call to .
The type indicates the set of statistics available through the object in a particular iteration step.
A value of "inbound-rtp" indicates that the statistics available in the current step are those defined in .
